title: 109_hr377
content: The Act may be cited as the "Honoring Every Requirement of Exemplary Service Act of 2005" or the "HEROES Act of 2005". It includes enhancements to death gratuity. The "HEROES Act of 2005" includes enhancements to death gratuity, increasing the amount to $100,000 for deaths resulting from combat-related causes or causes incurred in designated operations or areas. The death gratuity payable under the "HEROES Act of 2005" is $100,000 for deaths from combat-related causes or causes incurred in designated operations or areas. The death gratuity for combat-related deaths is $100,000 under the "HEROES Act of 2005" and is subject to increases in rates of basic pay. The death gratuity for combat-related deaths is subject to adjustments under subsection (d) and additional gratuity may be paid by the Secretary of the military department concerned. In addition to the death gratuity payable under sections 1475 through 1477 of title 10, United States Code, the Secretary of the military department concerned shall pay a death gratuity for members of the Armed Forces who died before the enactment of this Act as a direct result of wounds, injuries, or combat-related deaths. The requirements of this subsection apply to members of the Armed Forces who died before the enactment of this Act as a direct result of wounds, injuries, or illnesses incurred in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom, or as described in section 1413a(e)(2) of title 10, United States Code, on or after October 7, 2001. The additional death gratuity for beneficiaries of deceased members of the Armed Forces is $238,000, applicable to those who died as a direct result of wounds, injuries, or illnesses incurred in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom after October 7, 2001. Beneficiaries of deceased members of the Armed Forces are entitled to receive the regular military death gratuity and an additional death gratuity of $238,000 if the member died as a direct result of wounds, injuries, or illnesses incurred in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom after October 7, 2001. If there are multiple beneficiaries, the additional death gratuity will be divided among them based on the ratio of the regular military death gratuity. The additional death gratuity payable to a beneficiary is calculated based on the ratio of the regular military death gratuity received by that beneficiary to the total regular military death gratuity received by all beneficiaries. The additional death gratuity is calculated based on the ratio of the regular military death gratuity received by a beneficiary to the total regular military death gratuity received by all beneficiaries. Definitions for "additional death gratuity" and "regular military death gratuity" are provided in this subsection. SEC. 3. SERVICEMEMBERS' GROUP LIFE INSURANCE ENHANCEMENTS. Increased maximum amount under Servicemembers' Group Life Insurance to $400,000 or a lesser amount chosen by the member, with additional coverage for certain members. In subsection (e), the amount of insurance chosen by the member is increased to $400,000. Members serving in certain areas or operations may be eligible for additional coverage under Section 1967 of the title. In subsection (e), the insurance amount for members is increased to $400,000. Members serving in specific areas or operations may qualify for additional coverage under Section 1967 of the title. In subsection (e), members who die as a result of wounds, injuries, or illnesses incurred while serving in designated combat operations or zones are covered. Former members whose death is directly linked to injuries or illnesses from serving in such designated areas also qualify. The additional insurance amount provided for members who die as a result of injuries or illnesses incurred while serving in designated combat operations is $150,000, but it may be reduced if the member already has insurance exceeding $250,000. The insurance amount for a member under this subchapter cannot exceed $400,000. If a member already has insurance exceeding $250,000, the additional insurance amount will be reduced to comply with the $400,000 limit. During designated operations, the cost of insurance attributable to $150,000 coverage will be contributed as specified. During designated operations, the cost of insurance for a member under this subchapter, up to $150,000 coverage, will be contributed as specified and cannot be deducted from the member's pay. During designated operations, the cost of insurance for a member under this subchapter, up to $150,000 coverage, will be contributed from the appropriation made for active duty pay of the uniformed service concerned. The cost of insurance for a member under this subchapter, up to $150,000 coverage, will be contributed from the appropriation made for active duty pay of the uniformed service concerned. Section 1967 of the title is amended to increase the coverage amount to $400,000 and make conforming amendments. Section 1977(a) of the title is amended to increase insurance coverage to $400,000 and exclude additional insurance from Veterans' Group Life Insurance. Section 1967(a) is further amended regarding member elections to reduce or decline insurance. Section 1967(a) of the title is further amended to include regulations for member elections to reduce or decline insurance coverage under Veterans' Group Life Insurance. Section 1967(a) of the title is amended to include regulations for member elections regarding insurance coverage under Veterans' Group Life Insurance. A member with a spouse cannot choose to not be insured or be insured for less than the maximum amount provided. A member with a spouse cannot change insurance coverage without spousal consent. The spouse must also consent to any modifications to beneficiary designations. A member with a spouse must obtain spousal consent before changing beneficiary designations. The effective date for this section and its amendments is more than 90 days after the enactment of the Act.
